content:
The 0.000 validator is quite unfair because there's no test cases like it.
If you want to test 0, it's better to just write "0" as the input. If you want to force people to check for this edge case, then you should have at least one similar test case e.g. "9.000".

I just got 75% in a Shortest mode clash after getting 100% on test cases whereby I used a trick of evaluating the input as an expression, so that if it was an integer or float, my code could take it as it appears, but this "0.000" validator messed with my approach and cost me the clash.
Especially for shortest mode, it's important to not hide edge cases in the validators.

Very fun one, pretty easy in python with Fraction import :
from fractions import Fraction

D = float(input())
frac = Fraction(D).limit_denominator()
if frac.denominator == 1:
    print(frac.numerator)
else:
    print(f"{frac.numerator} / {frac.denominator}")
Why was this approved? The last two validators have trailing zeros in the input, unlike any of the IDE tests.

consider adding some inputs ending with multiple decimal zeros also to tests... There are two of them in validators (only in validators). I had this clash few times and rarely someone ends with 100%, I guess it is because of this...

The term you are looking for is reduced fraction:
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ReducedFraction.html

Although it is very intuitive for me, as in my native language, we use a similar word, but it should be mathematically correct.

On the other hand, I have two big problems for this. First of all, every rational number has infinitely many fraction forms, so this makes absolutely no sense at all:
"If there is no fraction for D"
What you want to say is that if D is integer then output A.

And an even bigger problem is with the hint. If D = 0.5 you expect the answer to be 1/2, but there are smaller integers that satisfy your hint, like -1/-2=-2/-4=...=-A/(-2A) for ANY positive integer A. So by your hint, there is no solution at all.

I know no one cares about this, and it will be accepted within no time, but this would make a great clash with the correct statement.

Nice clash.
One problem your last validator is too diffrent to your last test case. 0/0?! Change validator or test case please otherwise i like it very much ;)
You should define what is the smallest possible fraction for a number. I assume you mean the fraction involving the smallest number of digits, so maybe that's a way.

Add A and B to the description, and use them in the description of the output:
output: A / B

P.S.: sorry for my english. If I said something wrong, correct me
May I suggest to replace the NONE by either X / 1 or X ? It seems far more intuitive
I just inserted "NONE" for a little twist :). I could also replace it with X. **Just replaced it.**
Ok, added a hint for that. ;)
Tanks for your reply. You are right, "reduced fraction" is much better, I didn't think of that :). So it's also not necessary to specify that term.
The wording should be clarified, but I don't think it's worthy of rejecting just yet. Most of it can be solved by using the term 'reduced fraction' and using the definition from e.g. Wolfram.

@pathosDev: I'm really happy, that you took my advice. I'm quite fine with everything now, and agree on that it will be a fun CoC. Also, I know, how hard it is to speak a foriegn language (I had to take a German language exam today, a language that I don't speak), and how EXTREMELY hard to find the right terms for this topic. To be honest, we use a word very similar to "simplest form of the fraction" in Hungarian, so I automatically assigned them, but I suppose most people don't speak Hungarian. :D

@Qualia: I only refused it, in hopes others will notice what I wrote and the author has chance to think about my post. In this case, I got lucky, and CodinGame has a nice new problem.
